Award.AbstractNarration:
Testing Technologies in the Behavioral Sciences

Under the supervision of John Carson, Ph.D. student Katerina Mishuris will document the science behind and technologies developed for mental health and intelligence testing. With a focus on gifted children, and gender differences, the co-PI will contribute to the history of the behavioral sciences.

The identification and nurturing of gifted children, is important to contemporary democracies, where intellectual and artistic capital is essential to the advancement of national prosperity. This study promises to help behavioral scientists, who are exploring questions of talent, to better comprehend conflicting theories of child giftedness and the methods for its investigation, and hence allow them to become more sensitive and alert researchers and diagnosticians.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant for the project “Testing Technologies in the Behavioral Sciences” was used to support library and archival research by the co-PI for a dissertation fulfilling the requirements of the Ph.D. program in the Department of History at the University of Michigan. During the grant period, the co-PI collected and photocopied materials relating to the history of behavioral and developmental sciences at the following research sites: the Russian State Library in Moscow, the National Library of Russia in St. Petersburg, the Vernadsky National Library of Ukraine in Kiev, the archives of the Russian Academy of Science in Moscow and St. Petersburg and the archives of the Russian Academy of Education in Moscow. The co-PI has presented preliminary findings based on analysis of these materials at the British Society for the History of Science Annual Conference, held at the University of St. Andrews in July 2014, and at the History of Science Society’s meeting in Chicago in 2014. The research conducted for this project indicates that the advent of mental testing influenced the development of the Russian human and social sciences and the construction of child giftedness to a much greater degree than previously recognized.

The project will examine the role played by scientific methods in the making of gifted children into a distinct type and social group, giving particular attention to the advent of mental testing in Russian child science. It pursues the changing histories of gifted children and the investigative practices scientists developed to understand them in several scientific and medical contexts, rather than confining their appearance and function to a single field. Additionally, it will examine the role played by child giftedness in the formation of scientific knowledge and regulation of behavior. As such, it will be of importance for the fields of STS and the history and philosophy of science, where questions concerning the circulation of scientific knowledge and the coproduction of culture, politics, and science have become fundamental over the past few decades.

The project provides a historical contextualization for the scientific problem of the identification and nurturing of gifted children. As such, it will help behavioral scientists and educators, who are exploring questions of talent, to better comprehend the scientific language and the investigative methods they use in their everyday practice. Such comprehension, in turn, will help scientists to better navigate among and to deal with conflicting theories of child giftedness and the methods for its investigation, and hence allow them to become more sensitive and alert researchers and diagnosticians. The historical grounding that the present study provides is particularly relevant in this regard, as it was within the domain of Russian and Soviet behavioral sciences that important innovations in the diagnosis and development of giftedness in children were proposed. By bringing a rare corpus of original Russian materials that pertain to the Soviet child sciences into circulation among behavioral scientists in the United States and elsewhere, the project will introduce novel approaches for the scientific study of talent.
